A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of Map to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Image of a Map involves understanding the relationship between elements of two sets, A and B, through a function f. This concept is purely about the mapping of elements from one set to another and the resultant set formed by these mappings. It does not inherently require any operations such as addition or multiplication to be defined on these sets.

On the other hand, the concept of a Ring involves a set equipped with two binary operations, addition and multiplication, that satisfy certain algebraic properties. This concept is specific to algebraic structures and is unrelated to the basic definition of a function or its image.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of the Image of a Map do not depend on the properties or existence of a Ring. The Image of a Map is a fundamental concept in set theory and function theory, which can be understood independently of algebraic structures like Rings.
